description: From late Middle English congie, from Old French congié, congiet (modern French congé), from Latin commeātus (“passage, permission to leave”), from commeō (“I go and come”), from con- + meō (“I go, I pass”). Figurative senses generally borrowed from developments in French congé.

definitionGroups.group: Leave, formal permission for some action, (originally and particularly):

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Formal permission to leave; a passport.
(obsolete) Formal dismissal; (figurative) any dismissal; (originally & particularly humorously ironic) abrupt dismissal without ceremony.
(obsolete, Scotland) A fee paid to make another go away, (particularly) alms to a persistent beggar.
(archaic) A bow, curtsey, or other gesture (originally) made at departure but (later) including at greeting or in obeissance or respect.

verbs.description: congee (third-person singular simple present congees, present participle congeeing, simple past and past participle congeed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To give formal permission to leave; to dismiss.
(obsolete, transitive) To give formal permission to do something; to license.
(archaic) To take congee: to leave ceremoniously.
(archaic) To make a congee: to bow, curtsey, etc., (particularly dialectal) while leaving; (figuratively) to make obeissance, show respect, or defer to someone or something.

description: From Tamil கஞ்சி (kañci), possibly via Portuguese canje.

entries.meaning: (Asian cooking) A type of thick rice porridge or soup, sometimes prepared with vegetables and/or meat.
